abstract.text: A comparison of health care worker-collected foam and polyester nasal swabs in convalescent 2 COVID-19 patients

body_text.text: We compare the performance of polyester and foam swabs stored in different transport media. Interpretation: Polyester nasal swabs showed a reduction in performance from foam nasal 36 swabs, but may still provide a viable sample collection method given the current supply 37 shortages and public health emergency.

body_text.text: Additionally, swabs are typically stored and transported in VTM under refrigeration at or below 59 4°C. With VTM and swab supplies running low, and difficulties in obtaining sufficient 60 refrigeration space for the massive number of samples arriving at the labs to be tested, testing 61 requirements must be reevaluated to see if they can be safely altered 9, 10 . Recent work has shown 62 that saline may be a suitable replacement for VTM 11 . Since these findings were released, the Food 63 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 1, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.20083055 doi: medRxiv preprint and Drug Administration (FDA) has updated their testing recommendations to allow for a wider 64 variety of substances to be used for viral transport and stabilization and allow for self-collected 65 foam nasal swabs when VTM and NP swabs are not available 12 .

body_text.text: To address the dwindling supply of recommended swabs, we compared the relative performance 67 of polyester and foam nasal swabs for detecting SARS-CoV-2, stored and transported either in 68 VTM, saline, or in a dry tube. The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 1, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.20083055 doi: medRxiv preprint low platelet and low white blood cell counts, or acute facial trauma were excluded from the 86 study. Health care workers used a written consent form to explain the study and give eligible 87 patients the opportunity to decline. This study protocol was deemed to be part of a minimal risk swabs stored in VTM were refrigerated and sent to a reference laboratory for immediate testing, 97 while the dry polyester swab was stored without refrigeration for four days prior to testing. Due 98 to participant testing constraints, the polyester swab to be stored in a dry tube was not collected 99 from all patients. These swabs will be referred to as the foam, VTM polyester, and dry polyester 100 swabs.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Patients in the second cohort were also convalescing from COVID-19. They were recruited 102 immediately after their initial positive test result for SARS-CoV-2. During a single visit 103 (between two and seven days after initial diagnosis), these patients were swabbed twice: once 104 with a polyester swab and once with a foam swab. The order of sample collection was 105 randomized in the same manner as in the first cohort. Both samples were refrigerated at 4°C after 106 storage and tested in a reference laboratory as soon as possible.

Polyester nasal swabs detected four fewer positive cases than foam swabs and had an estimated 149 sensitivity (95% confidence interval) of 86•5% (77•3% -95•8%) when stored in VTM (Table 1) . 150 Additionally, there were eight visits with an inconclusive VTM foam swab and a negative VTM 151 polyester swab, but no visits with an inconclusive VTM polyester swab and a negative VTM 152 foam swab. In saline, the polyester swabs detected two fewer positive cases and had an estimated 153 . body_text.text: The current study has several limitations. All participants were convalescing COVID-19 patients, 198 and the time from first symptoms and first diagnosis to test date varied from test to test. As 199 . FIGREF0.text: Both polyester and foam nasal swabs were collected from convalescent COVID-19 24 patients at a single visit. Using the foam nasal swabs as the comparator, sensitivity of the 25 polyester swabs in each media were calculated, three by three tables were constructed to measure 26 concordance, and cycle threshold (Ct) values were compared.

FIGREF1.text: : 126 visits had polyester and foam swabs stored in viral transport media (VTM), 51 28 had polyester and foam swabs stored in saline, and 63 had a foam swab in VTM and a polyester 29 swab stored in a dry tube. Using nasal foam swabs as a comparator, polyester nasal swabs had a 30 sensitivity of 86•5% when both samples were stored in VTM, 86•7% when both samples were 31 stored in saline, and 72•4% when the polyester swab was stored dry and the foam swab was 32 stored in VTM. Polyester and foam Ct values from the same visit were correlated, but polyester 33 swabs showed decreased performance for cases with a viral load near the detection threshold 34 and higher Ct values on average.

FIGREF3.text: have previously tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 at any site from the original study 72 in Washington state were approached to return for additional testing 5 . A cohort of 63 positive 73 patients returned 7-9, 14-18, and 28-31 days after their initial positive diagnosis for longitudinal 74 sample collection, with swabbing continuing until all results for samples from a single visit were 75 negative. A second cohort consisted of participants who also previously tested positive. They 76 were contacted by ambulatory clinic staff and asked to return for a single visit as soon as 77 possible. 78 People who agreed to participate in either study were consented by medical staff. Participants 79 were evaluated at a designated ambulatory clinic site that only saw patients that were confirmed 80 with a prior positive SARS-CoV-2 reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) 81 test. Inclusion criteria included a previous positive SARS-CoV-2 test and the ability to consent 82 and agree to participate in the study. People who were not able to demonstrate understanding of 83 the study, not willing to commit to having all samples collected, had a history of nosebleed in the 84 past 24 hours, nasal surgery in the past two weeks, chemotherapy treatment with documented 85 .

FIGREF4.text: 88 research protocol by the Office of Human Research Affairs at UnitedHealth Group. 89 In the first cohort of 63 SARS-CoV-2 positive individuals, three nasal swabs were collected by a 90 health care worker from each patient: a foam swab and two polyester swabs. Patients born in an 91 odd numbered year first had their left nostril swabbed by the foam swab followed by their right 92 nostril being swabbed by the two polyester swabs. Patients born in an even numbered year had 93 their right nostril swabbed by the foam swab followed by their left nostril being swabbed by the 94 two polyester swabs. The first of the two polyester swabs was stored in VTM and the second 95 stored in a dry plastic tube without VTM. The foam swab was always stored in VTM. The two 96

FIGREF5.text: the head of the swab in the storage tube. All samples were marked with a patient study 111 number, the swab type, and the media type if any.112 RT-PCR was performed by a reference laboratory using the TaqPath TM COVID-19 Combo Kit 113 (ThermoFisher; A47814). Cycle threshold (Ct) values for all samples were reported back to the 114 clinical sites based on three different RNA targets: S Gene, ORF1ab, and N Gene. A higher Ct 115 value corresponds to a lower viral load. Per the reference laboratory standard protocols, a sample 116 was considered positive if two or three Ct values were less than or equal to 37, negative if all 117 three Ct values were greater than 37, and inconclusive otherwise. All inconclusive samples were 118 retested and the results of the retest were used, per manufacturer protocol. While a Ct value of 37 119 was used to determine the clinical results of the test, RT-PCR continued until 40 cycles were 120 completed. Therefore, the maximum Ct value in the data is 40. Foam swabs were stored in 1 mL 121 of VTM or 2 mL of saline and vortexed for three to five seconds. Polyester swabs were stored in 122 3 mL of VTM or 2 mL of saline and vortexed for three to five seconds. Dry polyester swabs 123 were eluted in 1 mL of phosphate-buffered saline and vortexed for 30 seconds followed by a ten 124 minute incubation. Ct values were normalized to estimated 3 mL Ct values to account for the 125 difference in volumes. Specifically, 1Ct was subtracted from all results stored in 2 mL of saline 126 or VTM, and 1•585 Ct was subtracted from polyester results stored in 1 mL. The Ct adjustments 127 assume 90-100% PCR efficiency and follow the formula 2 − = , where dCt is the necessary128

FIGREF6.text: the 3x3 confusion matrix showing the results of the polyester swabs against the results 131 of the foam swabs. We estimate the sensitivity of the polyester swabs using the foam nasal swab 132 as the comparator and report the 95% confidence intervals for the sensitivity estimates. For the 133 purposes of sensitivity calculations, inconclusive results were counted as negatives and foam 134 swabs were used as the comparator group. For each RNA target, we calculated the correlation of 135 the normalized Ct values between the foam and polyester swabs for all pairs where at least one 136 of the Ct values was < 40, indicating enough of the RNA target was detected to stop the RT-PCR 137 machine short of the maximum Ct value. For the same subset of polyester/foam swab pairs with 138 at least one Ct < 40 we also took the difference between the two Ct values and plotted the results 139 in a box plot. Positive difference values indicate a higher Ct (and thus lower viral load) in the 140 polyester samples and negative values indicate a higher Ct in the foam samples. 63 patients in the first cohort, 29 were positive at the 7-9 day visit, five were positive at 144 the 14-18 day visit, and zero were positive at the 28-31 day visit. One patient's swabs from the 145 28-31 day visit leaked in transport and were not tested. The second cohort consisted of 76 146 participants, of which 51 had their swab samples stored in saline and 26 had their swab samples 147 stored in VTM.

FIGREF8.text: 157 by the VTM samples and then the dry polyester versus VTM foam samples (Figure 1). While Ct 158 correlations were highest in saline, the foam Ct value was lower than the polyester Ct value more 159 than 63% of the time for the saline swabs, indicating the increased viral loads estimated using 160 foam swabs (Figure 2). Similar biases toward lower Ct values appeared in the VTM polyester 161 versus VTM foam and dry polyester versus VTM foam comparisons. The tendency toward lower 162Ct values for foam swabs is also apparent in the paired Ct plots(Figure 3).Figure 3is further 163 broken out by samples taken less than ten days from symptom onset and samples taken at least164    10 days from symptom onset inSupplemental Figures 1 and 2.

FIGREF9.text: of foam and polyester nasal swabs stored in VTM, in saline, or dry 167 demonstrated decreased, but potentially adequate performance of polyester swabs. The estimated 168 sensitivity of the polyester swabs was 86•5% and 86•7% in VTM and saline respectively. These 169 calculations were conservative because they counted inconclusive polyester results as negatives 170 for the purposes of sensitivity estimation, although no positive VTM foam swabs had a 171 corresponding inconclusive VTM polyester swab. Additionally, foam nasal swabs do not 172 represent the gold standard testing method, and the sensitivity calculations do not account for 173 cases where the foam swab returned a positive result but the polyester swab did not. It is 174 reasonable to believe these are indeed true positives when viewed in the light that all patients had 175 previously tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.

FIGREF10.text: While the estimated sensitivity above 86% may be deemed sufficient in times of a public health 178 emergency, the strength of the findings is diminished for cases with a viral load near the 179 positive/negative threshold of 37 cycles. This issue can be most clearly seen via the cluster of 180 points along the upper edge of the right hand side of the S Gene and N Gene correlation plots.181 These points represent cases where foam swabs detected virus and the polyester did not. This 182 finding is also reflected in the eight previously mentioned inconclusive VTM foam results that 183 were negative for the VTM polyester swab. All three polyester versus foam swab comparisons 184 exhibited a tendency for the foam swab to have lower Ct values than the polyester swab, 185 indicating the foam swab's superior ability to detect virus. Despite these reductions in 186 performance, polyester swabs in VTM or saline may be an adequate sample collection method in 187 cases where foam nasal and NP swabs have been entirely exhausted, a situation which exists in 188 many locations. 189 The dry polyester swabs showed poor performance, but were put at a disadvantage by the study 190 design. The degradation in performance of the dry swabs could arise from the lack of transport 191 media, lack of refrigearation, extended time before testing, decreased sample collection due to it 192 being the third swab in a nostril, or a combination of these factors. Dry swabs were only 193 collected for the first follow-up visit in the cohort of 63 patients that also had swabs stored in 194 VTM, resulting in a smaller sample size and different time since symptom onset than the other 195 comparisons. Dry swabs have been found to have high sensitivity in other diagnostic settings and196

FIGREF11.text: further from their diagnosis date their viral loads dropped, creating more 200 cases where the Ct values were near the border of detection. Other research has suggested viral 201 load may have already peaked at the time of diagnosis followed by a slow decline over time 15 . 202 The samples from this study may not be representative of testing in newly infected patients who 203 are seeking their first SARS-CoV-2 test. Additionally, because no NP swabs were obtained for 204 this study, performance of the polyester swab cannot be directly compared to the FDA's 205 preferred swabbing method 12 . Although final Ct values were adjusted for varying amounts of 206 transport media, imprecision in these adjustments could alter the VTM polyester versus VTM 207 foam comparison. Finally, the study was not designed to compare the performance of VTM and 208 saline or to estimate an interaction of swab type and transport media type. 209 Despite these limitations, polyester swabs stored in VTM or saline may be a viable sample 210 collection method for COVID-19 testing, especially in light of the shortages of other swab types. 211 The viability of polyester swabs is most clearly demonstrated via the high correlation between 212 polyester and foam Ct values from the same visit. Any recommendation for polyester swab usage 213 should bear in mind that the decrease in performance near the border of detection may lead to 214 false negatives in patients with low viral loads. 215 Data Sharing Statement: 216A deidentified dataset will be provided upon reasonable request to the corresponding author.

FIGREF14.text: Plots showing the difference in cycle threshold (Ct) of the polyester and foam swabs 238 collected at the same visits. Positive values represent higher Ct values in the polyester swab. The 239 dashed red line represents equivalent Ct values. The percentage of samples for which the foam 240 swab has a lower Ct value is shown below each sub-plot.

FIGREF15.text: Paired Ct plots showing the polyester and foam Ct values for each transport media and 244 target gene combination considered. Swabs collected at the same visit are connected by

TABREF0.text: In the few months since the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began tracking cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), more than 800,000 people have officially tested positive in the United States alone, resulting in more than 44,000 deaths 1 . The exponential spread of SARS-CoV-2 has resulted in an enormous demand for testing for the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes the disease. This increased demand has put a strain on every level of the system from personal protective equipment (PPE) worn by health care workers while administering the test, to swabs for collecting the samples, to viral transport media (VTM) to store the sample until tested, to laboratory capacity 2,3,4 . Efforts to provide viable alternatives for each of these supply shortages are 49 crucial to keeping the healthcare workforce safe and the testing throughput high.The shortages of PPE and swabs are driven, in part, because the originally recommended nasopharyngeal (NP) test cannot be self-administered, requiring a change in PPE for each test. A recent study showed that patient-collected foam nasal swabs were comparable to health care worker-collected NP swabs for detecting SARS-CoV-2 virus, providing a safer and less invasive sampling method 5 . These results validate findings for influenza testing 6,7 . While these results open the possibility of using patient-collected foam nasal swabs for sample collection, reducing the risk of viral exposure for health care workers, several issues remain. In the United States, foam nasal

TABREF1.text: sensitivity of 86•7% (74•5% -98•8%) (Table 2). The dry polyester swabs detected five fewer cases than foam swabs in VTM and had an estimated sensitivity of 72•4% (56•1% -88•7%)
